Comment:
I was WAY behind in this game due to an early blunder-- a simple pawn fork I overlooked that cost me a piece.  This game is an excellent example of how you shouldn't give up when you are behind.  At one point, I was down 5 points and was still fortunate enough to win the game.

lrgraham
I wasn't familiar with the King's Gambit....
I wasn't familiar with the King's Gambit....
...so I played the best move according to GameKnot's Game Database.
Preparing for Queenside castle later on...
Preparing for Queenside castle later on...
Preparing for Queenside castle later on...
Preparing for Queenside castle later on...
Preparing for Queenside castle later on...
Preparing for Queenside castle later on...
a good move by white, preventing me from moving Bg4, pinning his Knight at f3 to his Queen!
Everything looks pretty normal so far...
Everything looks pretty normal so far...
Everything looks pretty normal so far...
Everything looks pretty normal so far...
Until now... see any problems with my last move?
Black sure did!  As you can see, even a lowly pawn can win a piece... I can only move my Bishop OR my Knight, but not BOTH-- and he wins the other!
Counterattack was my chosen defense....
He still takes the Knight...
He still takes the Knight...
...but by attacking his Queen, this prevents him from playing cxb7, threatening to Queen his pawn!
...but by attacking his Queen, this prevents him from playing cxb7, threatening to Queen his pawn!
Net damage is -2, but White's not done yet.  Note where the White Queen had to move to take the Bishop...

Now, I give him three choices:  
1.  Blocking with Be3 allows me to capture his Bishop with my pawn; blocking with Queen or Rook wouldn't even be considered.
2.  Kh2 or Hh1 would allow Qh4 , losing momentum and exposing his King...  and finally...
3.  Kf8, safely (?) nestling his King between Rook and Queen.
Continuing the attack with my Queen, I threaten Qh1  and also attack his Rook at e1
White develops his othe bishop, possibly looking at Bg3 or Qg3.  This gives me time to...
...protect my King by castling Queenside.
Now I'm down by 4, and he's threatening to queen his pawn.  Fortunately, I see it appears he is planning to protect the pawn with e5, so to avoid the discovered attack on my King, I play...
Kb8, blocking the pawn's progress, and avoiding giving up a free move due to the check from his Queen.
He attacks the Bishop, planning to either develop more pieces or continue to swap me down....
